Select a page which provides information: Select a page which provides information about your diversity policies for %1$sstaffing%2$s, %1$shiring%2$s and %1$semployment%2$s.

Select a page which describes the person: Select a page which describes the personal, organisational, and corporate %1$sstandards%2$s of %1$sbehavior%2$s expected by your organisation.
Select a page which outlines your proced: Select a page which outlines your procedure for addressing %1$serrors%2$s (e.g., publishing retractions or corrections).
Select a page which describes how your o: Select a page which describes how your organisation collects and responds to %1$sfeedback%2$s, engages with the %1$spublic%2$s, and prioritises %1$stransparency%2$s.
Select a page which describes the owners: Select a page which describes the ownership structure of your organisation. It should include information about  %1$sfunding%2$s and %1$sgrants%2$s.
Select a page which describes the editor: Select a page which describes the editorial principles of your organisation. %1$sWhat%2$s do you write about, %1$swho%2$s do you write for, and %1$swhy%2$s?
Select the pages on your website which c: Select the pages on your website which contain information about your organisational and publishing policies. Some of these might not apply to your site, and you can select the same page for multiple policies. %1$sLearn more about why setting your site policies is important%2$s.
Add a 'disallow' rule to your robots.txt: Add a 'disallow' rule to your robots.txt file to prevent crawling by Google's AdsBot. You should only enable this setting if you're not using Google Ads on your site.
Lots of web traffic comes from bots craw: Lots of web traffic comes from bots crawling the web. Some of these can be beneficial to your site or to your business, but some just waste resources. Blocking unwanted bots can save energy and help with site performance.
Add a \u2018disallow\u2019 rule to your: Add a ‘disallow’ rule to your robots.txt file to prevent crawling of URLs like %1$s, %2$s and %3$s.

Choose whether your site represents an o: Choose whether your site represents an organisation or a person. %1$sLearn more about the differences and choosing between Organisation and Person%2$s.
Limit the length of internal site search: Limit the length of internal site search queries to reduce the impact of spam attacks and confusing URLs. Please enter a number between 1 and 50.
Prevents specific URL parameters from be: Prevents specific URL parameters from being removed by the above feature. E.g., adding %1$s will prevent %2$s from being redirected to %3$s. You can add multiple parameters and separate them by using enter or a comma.
Consolidates WordPress' multiple site se: Consolidates WordPress' multiple site search URL formats into the %1$s syntax. E.g., %2$s will redirect to %3$s

An organization name and logo need to be: An organisation name and logo need to be set for structured data to work properly. Since you haven’t set these yet, we are using the site name and logo as default values. %1$sLearn more about the importance of structured data%2$s.
This info is intended to appear in %1$sG: This info is intended to appear in %1$sGoogle's Knowledge Graph%2$s.
Enable the %1$s XML sitemaps. A sitemap: Enable the %1$s XML sitemaps. A sitemap is a file that lists a website's essential pages to make sure search engines can find and crawl them.
The %1$s icon in the top admin bar provi: The %1$s icon in the top admin bar provides quick access to third-party tools for analysing pages and makes it easy to see if you have new notifications.
Allows for Facebook and other social med: Allows for Facebook and other social media to display a preview with images and a text excerpt when a link to your site is shared. Keep this feature enabled to optimise your site for social media.
Get recommendations for relevant posts t: Get recommendations for relevant posts to link to and set up a great internal linking structure by connecting related content.
Count the number of internal links from: Count the number of internal links from and to your posts to improve your site structure.
Mark and filter your cornerstone content: Mark and filter your cornerstone content to make sure your most important articles get the attention they deserve. To help you write excellent copy, we’ll assess your text more strictly.
Get more insights into what you are writ: Get more insights into what you are writing. What words do you use most often? How much time does it take to read your text? Is your text easy to read?
The inclusive language analysis offers s: The inclusive language analysis offers suggestions to write more inclusive copy, so more people will be able to relate to your content.
The SEO analysis offers suggestions to i: The SEO analysis offers suggestions to improve the findability of your text and makes sure that your content meets best practices.
Usage tracking allows us to track some d: Usage tracking allows us to track some data about your site to improve our plugin. %1$sLearn more about which data we track and why%2$s.
A link to the archive for the post autho: A link to the archive for the post author, with the author's name as anchor text.

Determine how your %1$s pages should loo: Determine how your %1$s pages should look in search engines. You can always customise the settings for individual %1$s pages in the %2$s metabox.
Set the basic info for your website. You: Set the basic info for your website. You can use %1$stagline%2$s and %1$sseparator%2$s as %3$sreplacement variables%4$s when configuring the search appearance of your content.

Tell us if you have any other profiles o: Tell us if you have any other profiles on the web that belong to your organisation. This can be any number of profiles, like YouTube, LinkedIn, Pinterest, or even Wikipedia.
You can determine the title and descript: You can determine the title and description for the blog page by %1$sediting the blog page itself%2$s.
Prevent crawling of internal site search: Prevent crawling of internal site search URLs
Block internal site searches which match: Block internal site searches which match the patterns of known spam attacks.
Block internal site searches which conta: Block internal site searches which contain complex and non-alphanumeric characters, as they may be part of a spam attack.
Enables advanced settings for protecting: Enables advanced settings for protecting your internal site search URLs.
Your internal site search can create lot: Your internal site search can create lots of confusing URLs for search engines, and can even be used as a way for SEO spammers to attack your site. Most sites will benefit from experimenting with these protections and optimisations, even if you don’t have a search feature in your theme.
Please tell us more about your organizat: Please tell us more about your organisation. This information will help Google to understand your website, and improve your chance of getting rich results.
Add a \u2018disallow\u2019 rule to your: Add a ‘disallow’ rule to your robots.txt file to prevent crawling of WordPress' JSON API endpoints.
Remove JavaScript used for converting em: Remove JavaScript used for converting emoji characters in older browsers.
Remove URLs which provide alternative (l: Remove URLs which provide alternative (legacy) formats of all of the above.
Remove URLs which provide information ab: Remove URLs which provide information about your search results.
Remove URLs which provide information about your recent posts, for each custom taxonomy.
Remove URLs which provide information about your recent posts, for each tag.
Remove URLs which provide information about your recent posts, for each category.
Remove URLs which provide information about your recent posts, for each post type.
Remove URLs which provide information about recent posts by specific authors.
Remove URLs which provide information about recent comments on each post.
Remove URLs which provide an overview of: Remove URLs which provide an overview of recent comments on your site.
Remove URLs which provide an overview of your recent posts.
WordPress outputs your content in many d: WordPress outputs your content in many different formats, across many different URLs (like RSS feeds of your posts and categories). It’s generally good practice to disable the formats you’re not actively using.
Remove links which allow others sites to: Remove links which allow others sites to ‘ping’ yours when they link to you.
Remove information about the plugins and: Remove information about the plugins and software used by your site.
Remove links used for embedding your con: Remove links used for embedding your content on other sites.
Remove links used by external systems fo: Remove links used by external systems for publishing content to your blog.
Remove links to the location of your sit: Remove links to the location of your site’s REST API endpoints.
Remove links to WordPress' internal 'sho: Remove links to WordPress' internal 'shortlink' URLs for your posts.
Removes unknown URL parameters via a %1$: Removes unknown URL parameters via a %1$s redirect. E.g., %2$s will be redirected to %3$s
Replaces %1$s tracking parameters with t: Replaces %1$s tracking parameters with the (more performant) %2$s equivalent, via a %3$s redirect. E.g., %4$s will be redirected to %5$s
Users and search engines may often reque: Users and search engines may often request your URLs whilst using query parameters, like %1$s. These can be helpful for tracking, filtering, and powering advanced functionality - but they come with a performance and SEO ‘cost’. Sites which don’t rely on URL parameters might benefit from using these options.
WordPress adds a lot of links and conten: WordPress adds a lot of links and content to your site's %1$s and HTTP headers. For most websites you can safely disable all of these, which can help to save bytes, electricity, and trees.
Make your site more efficient and more e: Make your site more efficient and more environmentally friendly by preventing search engines from crawling things they don’t need to, and by removing unused WordPress features. %1$sLearn more about crawl settings and how they could benefit your site%2$s.
Choose the general appearance of your br: Choose the general appearance of your breadcrumbs.
You can always choose to enable\/disable: You can always choose to enable/disable them for your theme below. This setting will not apply to breadcrumbs inserted through a widget, a block or a shortcode.

Disabling this will redirect the %1$s to: Disabling this will redirect the %1$s to your site's homepage.
Unfortunately, this means that all your: Unfortunately, this means that all your unsaved changes will be lost. You can try and refresh this page to resolve the problem. If this error still occurs, please get in touch with our support team, and we'll get you all the help you need!

This field updates the %1$stagline in yo: This field updates the %1$stagline in your WordPress settings%2$s.
Disabling this means that %1$s pages cre: Disabling this means that %1$s pages created by WordPress will not be indexed by search engines and will be excluded from XML sitemaps.
When you upload media (e.g. an image or: When you upload media (e.g. an image or video), %5$s automatically creates a %3$s page (attachment URL) for it. These pages are quite empty and could cause %1$sthin content problems and lead to excess pages on your site%2$s. Therefore, %4$s disables them by default (and redirects the attachment URL to the media itself).
We recommend keeping %1$s pages disabled: We recommend keeping %1$s pages disabled. This will cause all attachment URLs to be redirected to the media itself.
Format-based archives can cause duplicat: Format-based archives can cause duplicate content issues. For most sites, we recommend that you disable this setting.
Disabling this means that %1$s will not: Disabling this means that %1$s will not be indexed by search engines and will be excluded from XML sitemaps. We recommend that you disable this setting.
%1$s can cause duplicate content issues. For most sites, we recommend that you disable this setting.
%1$s (e.g. %2$s) are based on publicatio: %1$s (e.g. %2$s) are based on publication dates. From an SEO perspective, the posts in these archives have no real relation to the other posts except for their publication dates, which doesn’t say much about the content. They could also lead to duplicate content issues. This is why we recommend you to disable %3$s.

Disabling this means that %1$s without a: Disabling this means that %1$s without any posts will not be indexed by search engines and will be excluded from XML sitemaps.
If you're running a one author blog, the: If you're running a one author blog, the %1$s (e.g. %2$s) will be exactly the same as your homepage. This is what's called a %3$sduplicate content problem%4$s. If this is the case on your site, you can choose to either disable it (which makes it redirect to the homepage), or prevent it from showing up in search results.

WordPress loads lots of resources, some: WordPress loads lots of resources, some of which your site might not need. If you’re not using these, removing them can speed up your pages and save resources.

Category URLs in WordPress contain a pre: Category URLs in WordPress contain a prefix, usually %s. Show or hide that prefix in category URLs.

This Yoast SEO REST API endpoint gives y: This Yoast SEO REST API endpoint gives you all the metadata you need for a specific URL. This will make it very easy for headless WordPress sites to use Yoast SEO for all their SEO meta output.

Verify your site with different tools. T: Verify your site with different tools. This will add a verification meta tag to your homepage. You can find instructions on how to verify your site for each platform by following the link in the description.
By default only editors and administrato: By default only editors and administrators can access the Advanced and Schema section of the %1$s sidebar or metabox. Disabling this allows access to all users.
Allows for Twitter to display a preview: Allows for Twitter to display a preview with images and a text excerpt when a link to your site is shared.

Automatically add content to your RSS. T: Automatically add content to your RSS. This enables you to add links back to your blog and your blog posts, helping search engines identify you as the original source of the content.
